awd_titl_txt: PFC:  Center for the Physics of Living Cells
awd_abstract_narration:
Describing complex living systems in a quantitative, physically-based manner is extremely difficult. Through this Physics Frontiers Centers award the Center for the Physics of Living Cells (CPLC) brings experimentalists and theorists together to address the technical challenges at the interface of physics and biology specifically on the cellular level. By the development and deployment of novel techniques from experimental, theoretical, and computational physics, the CPLC will create a dynamic narrative of living cells, expanding the physical description from molecular scales to whole cells and multicellular collections.  Exploring such topics as real-time molecular mechanics and the statistical physics of intermediate size systems will inform and advance areas in both biology and physics. CPLC activities will foster the training and development of multidisciplinary scientists at the junction of physics and biology, including ''bootcamps'' and summer school workshops for undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral researchers.  The CPLC will also operate diverse outreach programs targeting high school teachers and students, bilingual communities, and the general public.

The CPLC seeks to transform the understanding of how cells function from molecular to macroscopic scales, communicate, respond to external stimuli, and even evolve. These goals will be approached through a variety of research activities including the development of new biophysical techniques that can measure individual molecules and cells and observe how cells interact to create new phenomena. Another activity concerns the quantification of intracellular complexity, including the measurement of RNA and protein dynamics. Further investigations involve probing how the properties of multicellular systems arise from the interactions of single cells. Experimentalists and theorists at the CPLC will collaborate closely to develop novel multi-scale computational tools to simulate systems on a wide range of times, scales, and complexity.

This Physics Frontiers Centers award is co-funded by the Physics Frontiers Centers program in the Division of Physics and the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Division of Chemistry within the Directorate of Mathematical and Physical Sciences, and by the Molecular Biophysics program in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences within the Directorate for Biological Sciences.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of the NSF Center for the Physics of Living Cells (CPLC) at the University of Illinois was to create a quantitative, predictive, and physically-based description of living systems.  This formidable challenge required the collective efforts of experimental, computational, and theoretical biophysicists assembled into a team of collaborating scientists. The Center has had the broader impact of creating a dynamic, diverse community of early-career scientists trained in interdisciplinary science, who have taken leadership positions in academia and industry launched by their experiences in the CPLC.  Through its popular summer schools, workshops, and publications, the CPLC has communicated the exciting science emanating from its joint experimental and theoretical research efforts to researchers nationally and internationally.  It has provided inspiration to a broader community that includes school children, high school science teachers, and the public-at-large.

Living systems represent the highest level of organization known, capable of self-organized hierarchical assemblages and open-ended growth in complexity. How such physical systems, ultimately composed of molecules, “come to life” remains one of the greatest intellectual challenges of our time. To tackle this challenge, the CPLC has developed physics-based techniques that make major advances in imaging, molecular manipulation, computer simulation, and theoretical analysis of processes occurring at the molecular, cellular, and organismal level. These advances have enabled many groundbreaking scientific discoveries, of which we highlight a few. One such example is the discovery of a “mechanical code” of the genome, by which DNA flexibility (and its modulation by sequence and epigenetic modifications) encodes regulatory information in gene expression. Using novel single-molecule methods in tandem with computational modeling, the structure-function relationships in DNA processing machines can be probed in unprecedented detail, and this understanding exploited to bioengineer these molecular machines to perform desired tasks for biotechnological applications. New fluorescence labeling approaches have led to breakthroughs in live cell imaging, and used, for example, to localize the critical proteins in learning and memory in the synapses of live neurons. In addition, the CPLC has spurred major advances in GPU computation and visualization to allow modeling of biological processes that are realistic on both spatial and temporal scales. These efforts have made it possible to simulate systems across a wide range in scales: quantum mechanical enzymatic reactions, very large (>10 million atoms) macromolecular systems in all-atom detail, and complex biochemical reaction networks in the whole cell.

Many of these advances, disseminated since the CPLC’s renewal in 2014 through over 340 papers in the most high-impact scientific journals, have prominently involved collaborations between the participating senior investigators. Collaboration was vital for the success of the projects, because they involved the combination of experimental, computational, and theoretical techniques, as well as diverse biological and physical perspectives on the underlying phenomena. The Center framework and the unrivalled shared facilities that it enabled was critical in catalyzing these collaborative efforts.

Beyond the broader impacts of its scientific efforts, the CPLC has built a highly successful track record of training, education, and outreach for the scientific, K-12, and general public communities. The CPLC trained and mentored a cadre of postdocs, graduate students, and undergraduates across disciplines. 16 outstanding junior researchers were recruited through its competitive Postdoctoral and Graduate Fellowship programs. CPLC postdocs and graduate students in all have obtained 50 prestigious tenure-track faculty positions around the world since 2014. The CPLC led training and community-building efforts at the local, national, and international levels through Center-sponsored seminars, workshops, and courses; training of teaching fellows in research-based outreach programs; and participation in NSF international student exchange programs and the Physics of Living Systems Graduate Student Research Network. The Center’s signature national and international science outreach program, the CPLC Summer School, trained 167 early-career researchers from 79 institutions in advanced physical biology techniques from 2014 to 2019. Since its inception, the Center has developed a host of K-12 outreach activities focusing on inclusion of underrepresented groups in the sciences. These included a bilingual science and engineering program with the local school district for underrepresented elementary school students; research experiences for high school students; and the Physics of Life summer school for high school science teachers. In all, these activities and other annual on- and off-campus public events have impacted over 1,000 K-12 students and over 50 science teachers.
